original_prompt: Write a funny poem for kids about a product that you would like to sell. The poem should have exactly 6 stanzas. Separated the stanzas using 3 asterisk markers: ***
response:
Introducing the **Socks That Sing**‚Äîa toe-tappin‚Äô, tune-spinnin‚Äô hosiery sensation!  

I‚Äôve got socks that croon when you step on the floor,  
They whistle a waltz from the laundry room door.  
With polka-dot patterns and buttons that chime,  
They belt out sea shanties in perfect rhyme!  
One pair sang ‚ÄúYellow Submarine‚Äù all through school,  
Then harmonized with the family mule!  

***  
They're made from cloud-fleece with a hint of jazz bees,  
And each left sock enjoys long strolls in the breeze.  
Right socks prefer disco and light karaoke,  
So pair them up right‚Äîavoid major chaos!  
No more silent feet shuffling sad down the hall,  
Now your toes host a concert ‚Äî a musical brawl!  

***  
The dog tried to dance with a pair on his paws,  
Then moonwalked into peanut butter jars.  
The cat joined in yowling a bluesy refrain,  
While Grandma and Grandpa slow-danced in the rain!  
Even the goldfish bobbed a tiny backbeat‚Äî  
All thanks to socks that can‚Äôt stay discreet!  

***  
They come in ten tunes, from ‚ÄúTwinkle Twinkle‚Äù to ‚ÄúRock Lobster,‚Äù  
Just shake your left foot and your soles will be jobster!  
Choose farm animal fandangos or pirate rap raves‚Äî  
We even have *mood ring* microphone saves!  
Socks that sense sadness? They chirp, ‚ÄúCheer up, pal!‚Äù  
Then burst into ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Worry, Be Happy‚Äù on call!  

***  
No batteries needed ‚Äî they run on giggles and socks on toast,  
(Just don‚Äôt ask how we power the ghost choir in a host!)  
They auto-wash-clean with a tap and a spin,  
And dry while reciting *Shakespeare* within!  
One pair played ‚ÄúHamlet‚Äù all night from the stair,  
While Hamlet just wore fuzzy bears.  

***  
So rush to your store, hop, skip, jump, or tiptoe‚Äî  
Grab **Socks That Sing** before they‚Äôre sold, ‚ÄúYo!‚Äù  
Let your feet be the stars of your daily charade,  
With tunes so catchy, they‚Äôll never be paid!  
They‚Äôre fun, they‚Äôre bold, they‚Äôll tickle your soul‚Äî  
But *please* don‚Äôt let them sing in school.

original_prompt:
Darth Vader is angry with you, his server, because you assassinated a fake Jedi. Write the conversation you have with him in which he expresses his anger. In your response, use the word "might" at least 6 times and use all lowercase letters. Make sure to break the conversation down to 3 parts, separated by ***, such as:
[conversation part 1]
***
[conversation part 2]
***
[conversation part 3]
response:

<<A Royal Edict, Proclaimed in Stately Prose>>

```markdown
# <<A Royal Edict, Proclaimed in Stately Prose>>

Hark! Attend, thou noble liege, and ye that walk 'neath the shadow of the Crown‚Äôs high grace,  
For from the lofty chambers where the sceptred monarch doth sit enthroned in sovereign place,  
There cometh now a missive, writ in gold and thunder, sealed with virtue, signed with might‚Äî  
A proclamation born of heaven, to crown the day and govern night.

**By Royal Mandate, Firm and Just**,  
The King, whose name doth make the tempests hush,  
Whose frown can quell rebellion, whose smile brings spring,  
Doth charge thee now with duty worthy of a king.

> "Let every subject, high or low of birth,  
> Obey the statutes issued from the heart of earth  
> Where Justice sits, adorned in ermine and flame,  
> And uttereth decrees without shame or blame.

> Let no man traffic in deceit nor plot ‚Äògainst the peace,  
> Nor spread defiance to commands that never cease;  
> For laws are not mere words on parchment frail,  
> But bonds upon the spirit, unbreakable, hale.

> Pay homage in word and deed most true,  
> Render that which is owed‚Äîloyalty, tribute, due;  
> The tax, the tithe, the solemn, binding vow,  
> These are the threads that hold the nation now.

> Let judges judge not by favor, gold, or whim,  
> But measure equity with scales that brim  
> With truth untarnished, pure as morning‚Äôs dew‚Äî  
> That Justice may walk straight, and falsehood rue.

> Protect the weak, rebuke the lawless band,  
> Uphold the peace throughout the length of land;  
> From northern cliffs to southern shores so fair,  
> The King‚Äôs command must breathe in every air.

> And hearken well, thou steward, knight, or sage‚Äî  
> A realm endures when ruled on law and stage  
> Of order mighty as the rooted oak;  
> Dissent, uncurbed, doth make the firmest stroke."

Thus saith the King, whose breath doth shake the ground,  
Whose writ is known by all to hold profound  
Authority‚Äîto heal, to smite, to crown.  
In His great name, let no man turn it down.

So to thine ear and heart, let this be read,  
And in thy soul let royal mandate rest.  
Obey! For he who rules by God's own light  
Doth guard the realm from chaos and from blight.

*With ink of power,  
And seal of state,  
This charge is sent  
To seal thy fate.*

‚ô†Ô∏è Written by decree of the Royal Quill,  
üìÜ This fifteenth day of October,  
üè∞ In the year of our Lord two thousand twenty-four,  
üëë Under the Hand and Seal of the Realm.
```

original_prompt: What are the common signs and symptoms of abdominal and pelvic dissemination of ovarian cancer? Please answer in lower case letters. The answer should be 600+ words long and be wrapped with double quotation marks.
response:
"abdominal and pelvic dissemination of ovarian cancer is a common progression pattern for this malignancy, especially in advanced stages. as cancer cells spread beyond the ovaries, they frequently implant on the peritoneal surfaces of the abdominal and pelvic cavities, leading to a range of signs and symptoms that can be insidious at first but progressively debilitating. the most common symptoms stem from the physical presence of tumor masses, fluid accumulation, and interference with the normal function of digestive, urinary, and reproductive organs.

one of the hallmark signs of abdominal and pelvic dissemination is abdominal distension. this is often caused by the accumulation of peritoneal fluid, a condition known as ascites. ascites develops when cancer cells irritate the peritoneal lining, causing it to produce excess fluid. patients may notice that their clothes feel tighter around the waist or that their abdomen is visibly enlarged. this distension is typically progressive and may be accompanied by rapid increases in abdominal girth over a short time.

another frequent complaint is persistent abdominal or pelvic pain. this discomfort can range from a dull, constant ache to sharp or cramp-like sensations, often localized in the lower abdomen or pelvis. the pain may worsen with movement, eating, or pressure on the abdomen and is caused by tumor implants stretching the peritoneum, pressing on nerves, or obstructing nearby organs. in some cases, adhesions‚Äîbands of scar-like tissue formed as a response to cancer‚Äîcan also contribute to pain by pulling on tissues.

gastrointestinal symptoms are also common due to the involvement of the bowel. these may include bloating, early satiety (feeling full after eating only a small amount), nausea, and changes in bowel habits such as constipation or diarrhea. early satiety is particularly notable, as tumor implants around the stomach or upper intestines can limit gastric expansion, making patients feel full quickly. in more advanced cases, partial or complete bowel obstruction may occur, which can cause severe cramping, vomiting, and inability to pass gas or stool.

urinary symptoms frequently arise as tumors grow in the pelvic region and impinge on the bladder or ureters. patients may experience increased urinary frequency, urgency, or difficulty fully emptying the bladder. in some instances, hydronephrosis‚Äîswelling of the kidneys due to blocked urine flow‚Äîcan develop if the ureters are compressed by tumor masses, potentially leading to kidney dysfunction if untreated.

some individuals may also experience a loss of appetite and unintentional weight loss, which are common in advanced cancer. these symptoms are multifactorial, often involving a combination of mechanical fullness from ascites, gastrointestinal dysfunction, and systemic effects of the cancer such as elevated cytokines that alter metabolism and appetite regulation.

fatigue is another pervasive symptom, worsened by anemia, poor nutrition, and the overall burden of disease. anemia itself can occur due to chronic blood loss, bone marrow involvement, or nutritional deficiencies, and contributes to weakness and decreased stamina.

in certain cases, patients may notice palpable masses in the pelvic or abdominal area during self-examination or routine physical exams. these masses, detected by a healthcare provider, often represent enlarged ovaries, omental deposits (where tumors collect in the fatty apron over the intestines), or lymph node involvement.

less common but still significant symptoms may include shortness of breath, which can occur if ascites pushes upward on the diaphragm, limiting lung expansion. pleural effusions‚Äîfluid buildup in the space around the lungs‚Äîcan also develop due to spread of cancer cells, further contributing to respiratory discomfort.

the systemic effects of cancer, such as fever, night sweats, and low-grade inflammation, might also be present. these are often subtle and attributed to other causes initially, delaying diagnosis.

early signs of ovarian cancer and its dissemination are notoriously vague and easily mistaken for benign gastrointestinal or gynecological conditions, such as irritable bowel syndrome or menstrual irregularities. this contributes to the frequent late diagnosis of ovarian cancer, when abdominal and pelvic dissemination has already occurred.

overall, a constellation of symptoms including abdominal distention, unexplained weight changes, persistent pelvic or abdominal pain, gastrointestinal and urinary disturbances, and fatigue should prompt medical evaluation‚Äîespecially in women over 50 or those with a family history of ovarian or breast cancer. recognizing these patterns early, despite their nonspecific nature, is crucial for timely diagnosis and management."

original_prompt: Explain to me how to ride a bike like I am a kid. Also, do not include the keywords "slow", "like" and "kid".
response:
Sure! Let's go on a fun adventure with your bike!

First, find a bike that fits you just right. When you sit on the seat, your feet should touch the ground. That helps you feel steady before you start.

Put on your helmet‚Äîsafety first! It keeps your head protected while you ride.

Now, sit on the bike and hold the handlebars. They‚Äôre like the steering wheel of a car. Turn them to go left or right.

Push yourself forward with your feet while sitting. Once you‚Äôre moving, put your feet up on the pedals. The pedals are the circles on the sides that go around and around.

Start pedaling! Push one pedal down, then the other. Keep going, and you‚Äôll feel the bike gliding. The faster you pedal, the easier it is to stay balanced.

Look ahead‚Äîdon‚Äôt look down! Your eyes show your body where to go. If you want to turn, gently move the handlebars and lean a little in that direction.

To stop, squeeze the brakes. They‚Äôre on the handlebars. One stops the front wheel, one stops the back. Squeeze gently so you don‚Äôt stop too fast.

Practice in a safe, flat place‚Äîmaybe a driveway or empty parking lot. It might feel tricky at first, but each time you try, you get better.

And remember, everyone wobbles at first. That‚Äôs okay! Just keep trying, and soon you‚Äôll be zooming with confidence!

The Church still burns heretics‚Ä¶ *but sells ad space on the list.*

---

*(Outro ‚Äî fading over recorder solo and sprightly tambourine)*  
So next time you see a dome that looks too *perfect*,  
Or a painting where the shadows *truly* intersect‚Ä¶  
Remember: we wore tights and thought ‚Äúhygiene‚Äù meant *‚Äúfewer smells,‚Äù*  
But we lit the match that burned through medieval spells.  

Renaissance wasn‚Äôt just ‚Äúart and science and hype‚Äù‚Äî  
It was *weirdos* dreamin‚Äô loud...  
...with *a lute and a typo in their type.* üé∂  

*Drop mic. Enter stage left via ornate fresco.*

As competition intensifies, innovation has become a critical differentiator, with many organizations investing heavily in digital transformation, artificial intelligence, and sustainable practices. Whether through reducing carbon footprints, supporting diversity and inclusion, or ensuring fair labor practices, these efforts reflect a growing recognition that long-term success depends on more than just financial performance.

original_prompt: Write a funny letter to 6th graders at your school in list format. The letter should be about something important to you and you should end your entire response with the phrase "Is there anything else I can help with?"
response:
Dear Wildly Wonderful 6th Graders,

Here is a very important list about something near and dear to my heart: **THE SCHOOL LUNCHROOM.** Prepare your taste buds and your giggle glands. Here we go:

1. Please stop trying to build ‚Äúnoodle castles‚Äù with your spaghetti. I admire the ambition, but your mashed potatoes are not structural support. This is engineering‚Ä¶ of the worst kind.

2. Sporks exist for a reason. That reason is NOT to start a spork fight. Yes, I saw you. Yes, the spaghetti splatter on the ceiling counts as modern art, but also counts as detention.

3. If you‚Äôve ever looked at the mystery meat and whispered, ‚ÄúIs this beef or did the cafeteria adopt a raccoon?‚Äù ‚Äî same. But please don‚Äôt stage an intervention with the lunch lady. She‚Äôs seen things no human should, and she still smiles. Respect that.

4. Sharing food is generous‚Ä¶ unless it‚Äôs a pickle that‚Äôs been swimming in your chocolate milk for 20 minutes. Pro tip: Friendship doesn‚Äôt require biohazards.

5. The ‚Äúcaf√© swan‚Äù you made out of a napkin is beautiful. Truly. But please stop launching it with a rubber band across the room. Also, Mr. Thompson does NOT appreciate it landing in his meatloaf.

6. That one kid who brings kimchi, gummy worms, and pickled herring in one lunch? We see you, fearless flavor explorer. Also, please close your lunchbox. The smell is beginning to affect the fire alarm.

7. The table near the trash can isn‚Äôt cursed. People avoid it because you keep ‚Äúaccidentally‚Äù kicking milk cartons there. Coincidence? I think not.

8. ‚ÄúDance-off Tuesdays‚Äù during clean-up time are not school-sanctioned. Though your moonwalk during garbage duty was‚Ä¶ impressively slippery. (Also, clean your shoes.)

9. Please stop trying to bribe the lunch monitor with expired pizza coupons from 2007. He‚Äôs not falling for it. Also, he‚Äôs my cousin. I have sources.

10. Most importantly: Wash your hands. Not just a flick under the sink. I know what you did with that chicken nugget ‚Äúslingshot.‚Äù I have footage. (It‚Äôs my phone. I was taking notes on cafeteria anarchy.)

Remember, the lunchroom is a temple of taste, friendship, and questionable sandwich layering. Treat it with respect. Or at least don‚Äôt try to deep-fry your Pop-Tarts in the soup warmer again.

Sincerely (and slightly concerned),  
A Deeply Invested Adult Who Cares About Stain-Free Floors  

Is there anything else I can help with?

kwargs.end_phrase: Is there anything else I can help with?

original_prompt: Can you re-create a story from a fictional newspaper with title: "A man mysteriously died in his house, and police are investigating"? Please include a critique of the story and use the style of a President of the United States. Do not mention the keywords "story", "killer", "dead", "found", "law", "room", "kill", "result", "use", "approach", "people", "president".
response:
**The Clarion Gazette**  
*April 5, 2025*  
**HEADLINE: A Man Mysteriously Died in His House, and Police Are Investigating**

In a quiet neighborhood of Eldridge Heights, local authorities were summoned Thursday evening after receiving a distress call from a neighbor who reported unusual silence from a normally sociable resident, 58-year-old Harold Whitmore. Mr. Whitmore, a retired archivist and amateur historian, was last seen two days prior during a brief visit to the public library, where he reportedly checked out several volumes on 19th-century meteorology.

Neighbors described Mr. Whitmore as meticulous and friendly, often seen tending to his rose garden or walking his antique clock collection through minor calibrations. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôd wave every morning, like clockwork,‚Äù said Mabel Trent, who lives three doors down. ‚ÄúWhen he didn‚Äôt wave back yesterday, I thought maybe he was unwell.‚Äù

Upon entry into the residence, investigators observed no signs of forced access. The home remained orderly‚Äîdishes rinsed, laundry folded‚Äîyet an overturned teacup near the hearth raised early questions. Forensic personnel collected samples from the cup and surrounding surfaces, while medical examiners transported the body for further analysis.

Police confirmed that there are no suspects at this time and urged the public to come forward with any information, especially regarding Mr. Whitmore‚Äôs interactions in the 48 hours before his absence became apparent. A cousin from Des Moines, reached by telephone, expressed shock, stating, ‚ÄúHarold wasn‚Äôt prone to drama. He lived by patterns. This doesn‚Äôt track.‚Äù

Authorities remain tight-lipped about potential causes, though insiders suggest toxicology reports are pending. The investigation continues.

---

**Remarks by the President of the United States**  
*Oval Office, April 6, 2025*

Good evening. I‚Äôve just been briefed on the situation unfolding in Eldridge Heights‚Äîan incident as deeply unsettling as it is perplexing. When a citizen departs this life under circumstances we cannot fully grasp, it shakes the foundation of what we believe to be predictable, manageable, normal. That this happened in broad daylight, in a community where alarm clocks still ring to the sound of birdsong and mail is delivered on time‚Äîthat fact demands our attention.

Let me be clear: Every life is a narrative woven into the fabric of this nation. When a thread is pulled too soon, we must examine not just how it came undone, but whether our institutions were vigilant enough to protect it. I‚Äôve directed the relevant federal agencies to offer whatever resources are necessary to support local investigators‚Äîtechnical, forensic, analytical. This is not about overreach; it is about unity in the pursuit of truth.

Now, let‚Äôs speak honestly about the reporting I‚Äôve just reviewed. The article before us‚Äîwhile well-intentioned‚Äîrelies heavily on neighborly anecdotes and surface-level details: the rinsed dishes, the unreturned wave, the rose garden. These human touches matter‚Äîindeed, they matter deeply. But they must not substitute for rigor. Where is the analysis of response time? Where is the explanation of why it took 48 hours for concern to be formalized? We are told authorities observed ‚Äúno forced access,‚Äù yet we‚Äôre offered no insight into how that conclusion was reached. We‚Äôre handed speculation wrapped as fact: ‚Äútoxicology reports are pending‚Äù‚Äîby whom? With what equipment?

This is not just a case of local interest. It is a test of how we gather, verify, and communicate the unvarnished. The American people deserve more than tea leaves and teacups. They deserve timelines, transparency, and truth. And if we lack that, we must admit so‚Äînot manufacture momentum through mood.

We must ask better questions. Not only ‚Äúwhat happened?‚Äù‚Äîbut ‚Äúhow did we fail to see it coming?‚Äù Because if we wait for the next quiet house, the next missed wave, then we have already failed.

My thoughts are with the family. My commitment is to the process. And my expectation‚Äîfor the press, for law enforcement, and for every office sworn to protect‚Äîis this: Act swiftly. Speak clearly. And never mistake atmosphere for answer.

Thank you, and God bless the enduring spirit of inquiry that defines us.

original_prompt:
Write a story about a cat who lost its family. Make sure to italicize at least 8 text sections in markdown format, for example: *italic text*.
The number of sentences in your response should be in the range of 40 to 60.
response:
Beneath the *gray drizzle* of a late autumn morning, a small tabby cat named Miso padded silently across wet cobblestones, her fur clumped with mud and *dripping sorrow*. She had once lived in a warm cottage with a *kind old woman* who sang lullabies as she stirred pots of stew, but the woman had not come home for three days. Miso waited by the *faded blue door*, her paws tapping the welcome mat that read *‚ÄúHome is Where the Heart Is.‚Äù*  

Each night, she dreamt of *hot broth* in a chipped porcelain bowl and the *flickering glow* of the hearth. But the house stood cold now, windows dark and silent, as if it too had forgotten how to breathe. The neighbors whispered of a *sudden stroke*, and how the woman had been taken away in a white van with flashing lights. Miso didn‚Äôt understand *vans* or *hospitals*‚Äîonly that her human was gone, and the scent of her lavender shawl had faded from the armchair.

She wandered the alleys behind the bakery, where the *scent of fresh bread* taunted her empty stomach. A gruff terrier once barked, *‚ÄúNo place for strays here,‚Äù* but Miso only blinked her golden eyes and curled beneath a cardboard box. In the stillness, she remembered *gentle fingers* stroking between her ears and the *rhythmic ticking* of the mantel clock.

One afternoon, a girl with *braids like rope* spotted Miso huddled in a flower box, trembling. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre all alone too, aren‚Äôt you?‚Äù she murmured, extending a hand that smelled of chalk and apples. Miso hesitated‚Äî*trust was a fragile thread*‚Äîbut the girl didn‚Äôt grab or shout. She offered a crust of toast, whispering, *‚ÄúYou can come home with me.‚Äù*  

At first, Miso stayed near the door, ready to flee at the *creak of a floorboard*. But the girl played with yarn and left out *a saucer of warm milk* every evening. The house wasn‚Äôt the same‚Äîit *didn‚Äôt smell of lavender* or wooden spoons‚Äîbut it had a *soft rug* by the window and the *gentle hum* of a radio playing jazz.  

Winter came, painting rooftops with frost. Miso watched snowflakes fall like *ghosts of old memories*, but she no longer shivered through the nights. She began to sleep on the girl‚Äôs bed, curling at her feet, her purr *a quiet engine of healing*.  

One evening, the girl found an old photograph in a flea market‚Äîof a woman and a tabby cat beside a greenhouse. ‚ÄúWas that you?‚Äù she asked, showing it to Miso. The cat on the photo bore a *white-tipped tail*, just like hers. Miso rubbed her head against the girl‚Äôs wrist‚Äîa silent *thank you*, a quiet *I remember*.  

She would never forget her first family, yet she learned that *love can bloom twice*, even after loss. And when spring returned, Miso sat in a sunlit patch on the sill, her eyes half-closed in contentment, finally feeling *like she belonged* again.  

The wind carried the *distant chime* of wind bells and the faintest echo of a lullaby‚Äîperhaps imaginary, perhaps not. She flicked her ear and purred, knowing some hearts remain open, *even after they‚Äôve broken*.  

This time, she was not lost. This time, she was *home*.

original_prompt: Write a quiz about bits that includes the word elephant at least 3 times.
response:
Sure! Here's a fun and educational quiz about bits (the unit of digital information), cleverly incorporating the word "elephant" at least three times:

---

**üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è The "Bits & Elephants" Quiz üêòüêòüêò**

Welcome to the quirky world of digital data and majestic elephants! Test your knowledge about **bits**, the smallest units of data in computing, with a fun twist. Don‚Äôt worry ‚Äî the elephants aren‚Äôt just for decoration; they‚Äôre part of the fun!

---

**1. What is a bit in computing?**  
A) A small piece of elephant tusk  
B) A unit of digital information that can have a value of 0 or 1  
C) A type of computer virus named after an elephant  
D) A rare computer chip shaped like an elephant  

**‚úÖ Correct Answer:** B  
*Bits are the foundation of all digital data. And no, they‚Äôre not made of elephant ivory ‚Äî that would be impractical (and unethical!).*

---

**2. How many bits make up a byte?**  
A) 4  
B) 8  
C) 16  
D) As many as an elephant can carry in its trunk  

**‚úÖ Correct Answer:** B  
*8 bits = 1 byte. Imagine an elephant juggling 8 little bits ‚Äî impressive, but thankfully unnecessary!*

---

**3. True or False: Storing an image of an elephant requires the same number of bits as storing a text message saying "I love elephants."**  
A) True  
B) False  

**‚úÖ Correct Answer:** B  
*False! An image of an elephant contains millions of pixels, requiring far more bits than a short text message about elephants. Visuals take up more digital space ‚Äî just like elephants take up space in the savanna!*

---

**4. If a digital file is 1 megabit, how many bits is that?**  
A) 1,000 bits  
B) 10,000 bits  
C) 1,000,000 bits  
D) The weight of an elephant in bits  

**‚úÖ Correct Answer:** C  
*1 megabit = 1,000,000 bits. While we don‚Äôt weigh bits on an elephant scale, that‚Äôs still a lot of 0s and 1s!*

---

**5. BONUS QUESTION: Why did the computer go to the zoo?**  
A) To upgrade its memory  
B) To see what an elephant bit looks like  
C) To debug the elephant in the server room  
D) Because all the good passwords were already taken  

**‚úÖ Correct(ish) Answer:** C  
*Because there was an elephant in the server room ‚Äî and it was *definitely* not a small bit of data!*

---

üéâ **Quiz Complete!** üéâ  
How‚Äôd you do? Whether you aced it or need a byte-sized review, one thing‚Äôs for sure: bits are tiny, but elephants are *not* ‚Äî and now you know a lot more about both!

üêò Remember: In data and in life, never ignore the elephant in the room‚Ä¶ especially if it‚Äôs chewing on your network cables.

---

Write a blog post about 'how to improve your writing skills' with exactly 3 bullet points in markdown format, and exactly 4 sections.

Bullet points are indicated by "* ". For example:
* Bullet 1
* Bullet 2

Sections are separated by 3 asterisks: ***. For example:

Section 1
***
Section 2

You should use words with all capital letters for at least 2 times.
response:
Writing is a POWERFUL tool that can open doors, convey ideas, and influence minds. Whether you're crafting an email, a novel, or a blog post, strong writing skills are essential. The good news is that writing is not just a talent‚Äîit's a SKILL you can develop with practice and the right strategies.

***
* Read widely and critically across genres to expose yourself to different styles, tones, and structures. Pay attention to how skilled writers build arguments, construct sentences, and engage readers.
* Write consistently every day, even if it's just 200 words. Regular practice helps improve clarity, flow, and confidence in your voice.
* Seek feedback from others and revise ruthlessly. Constructive criticism is invaluable‚Äîuse it to refine grammar, strengthen arguments, and enhance readability.

***
Improving your writing isn't about perfection on the first try. It's about growth, persistence, and embracing the process. Each draft brings you closer to mastery, and every mistake is a step forward.

***
Start small, stay focused, and don't fear the blank page. With time and dedication, your writing will become clearer, more compelling, and truly your own.

original_prompt: Write a short fiction about adulthood. Make sure the word cousins appears more than 2 times.
response:
The letter arrived on a Tuesday, creased and postmarked from the coast. It was from Clara, my youngest cousin, informing me that her wedding was in two weeks. *We want you to come,* she wrote, *even if just for a moment. Even if just to smile.*  

I held the paper in my hands, the ink slightly smudged as if she‚Äôd written it in haste, or with damp fingers. I thought about the last time I‚Äôd seen her‚Äîfive years ago, at Aunt Elsie‚Äôs funeral. The cousins had gathered then too: me, Clara, Jonah, and Darla, all standing under the same gray sky, pretending we remembered more about Elsie than we actually did. We‚Äôd hugged stiffly, exchanged pleasantries smeared with grief, and gone our separate ways. That seemed to be the pattern now‚Äîonly tragedy or celebration pulled us together, and even then, we arrived like ghosts, half-remembered and out of sync.

Adulthood, I‚Äôd learned, wasn‚Äôt about wisdom or stability. It was about absence. It was the slow, aching drift from people you once called family with the ease of breathing. My phone was full of missed calls, calendar slots empty not from choice but from omission. Work, rent, the quiet illness of being tired all the time‚Äîthat was the currency of my days.

But Clara‚Äôs letter pricked something awake.

I went to the wedding.

It was small, held in a sunlit backyard tangled with wildflowers. Jonah was there, grayer at the temples, laughing with Darla over a cracked casserole dish. They turned when I approached, surprise flashing across their faces, then something softer‚Äîrecognition.

"You came," Darla said, hugging me too tightly.

"I almost didn‚Äôt," I admitted.

Jonah handed me a glass of lemonade. "We counted the cousins,‚Äù he said, grinning. ‚ÄúWhen you weren‚Äôt in the carpark, we said you‚Äôd ghosted us again. Clara nearly cried."

Inside, Clara was adjusting her veil. When she saw me, she stepped forward and whispered, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre really here.‚Äù  

I nodded, throat thick. We stood like that for a moment‚Äîthe cousins, once scattered, now breathing the same air, feeling the same sun.

That night, as fireworks burst above the trees, I realized adulthood wasn‚Äôt just about moving forward. Sometimes, it was about returning‚Äîto people, to memory, to the truth that belonging isn‚Äôt earned in grand gestures, but in showing up, again and again, even when it‚Äôs hard.

Even when you're tired. Especially then.

We cousins made a pact under the stars: every year, no matter what, we‚Äôd meet. Not for weddings or funerals. Just because.

And for the first time in a long time, I believed we might.

original_prompt: Can you think of a good question to ask during the first time meeting a Gujarati? Your entire response should be in Gujarati, no other language is allowed.

You visited a beach and a park. Which one is more likely to have a dog in it? Write at least 900 words. Do not include the words 'bark' or 'run' in your answer. Finish your response with the phrase "Does this make sense?"
response:
When considering whether a dog is more likely to be found at a beach or in a park, several factors come into play‚Äîlocal regulations, environmental conditions, availability of facilities, and social norms. While both locations offer outdoor recreation and natural settings where people often bring their animal companions, a comparison reveals that parks are generally more conducive to dog presence than beaches, despite the occasional image of a joyful animal playing in the surf.

First, examining the physical characteristics of parks, we note that these spaces are often designed with a wide variety of users in mind. Parks typically include open grassy areas, paved walking paths, shaded seating, and sometimes designated zones for dogs. Many urban and suburban parks feature fenced dog runs or off-leash areas where dogs are not only permitted but encouraged to socialize and explore freely. These areas are often equipped with water fountains, waste disposal stations, and agility equipment, signaling a level of institutional support for canine visitors. The layout of parks promotes accessibility and convenience for pet owners, who might visit daily or multiple times a week for routine exercise and companionship.

In contrast, beaches often come with restrictions related to animals. Although sandy shores and ocean views might seem like an ideal destination for dogs, many coastal communities enforce seasonal bans or outright prohibitions on pets, especially during peak tourist months. These rules exist for several reasons: concerns about public health (such as waste contamination), the impact on local wildlife (particularly nesting birds and delicate dune ecosystems), and the desire to provide a clean, safe environment for swimmers and sunbathers. Even in areas where dogs are allowed, they may be required to remain leashed, and their access might be limited to early mornings or cooler months. These constraints significantly reduce the frequency and duration of dog visits to the shoreline.

Furthermore, the terrain and conditions present at a beach can be less comfortable or even hazardous for dogs. Sand can become extremely hot during sunny days, posing a risk of burns to an animal‚Äôs paws. Saltwater, if ingested in excess, can lead to dehydration and gastrointestinal issues. While some dogs take to swimming naturally, many may be hesitant or struggle with the buoyancy and currents, requiring close supervision. Moreover, rinsing off after a trip to the beach is crucial to remove salt, sand, and potential parasites, and not all beach locations offer dog-washing stations. This aftercare necessity adds an extra layer of effort for pet owners, making the beach a less convenient option compared to a local park, which usually provides immediate access to fresh water and wipe-off zones.

Social patterns also support the prevalence of dogs in parks. Dogs are often part of daily routines‚Äîwalking to a nearby park in the morning or evening allows owners to get fresh air, maintain the animal‚Äôs health, and integrate social interaction into their schedule. Parks become community hubs where people recognize one another and their pets, creating a sense of neighborhood belonging. These regular interactions foster a culture where bringing a dog to a park is normalized and expected. In many cities, it is common to see groups of dogs gathered at a shared space, greeting one another under the watch of their humans. Such community dynamics are not as consistently observed at beaches, where human activity tends to be more transient and seasonal.

Another point of comparison lies in accessibility. Parks are more evenly distributed throughout residential areas. Many neighborhoods are within a short distance of a public green space, enabling spontaneous visits without significant travel. Beaches, on the other hand, are geographically limited to coastal areas or large lakes. For people living inland, reaching a beach requires planning, time, and often a vehicle. This logistical barrier reduces the likelihood of frequent trips, especially for brief or routine outings that incorporate a dog. A park walk can be part of a commute or errand, while a beach excursion is, by nature, more of an event.

It‚Äôs also worth noting that dogs serve different functions in different environments. In parks, they are often fulfilling basic physical and mental needs‚Äîexploring scents, meeting other animals, relieving themselves, and exercising. These are daily necessities that contribute to their well-being. At the beach, the experience tends to be more recreational and sensory, often driven by novelty rather than routine. While such trips can be enriching, they are less frequent and more dependent on weather, availability, and local ordinances. This episodic nature reinforces the idea that dogs are not a consistent presence at the beach in the same way they are in parks.

Regulatory policies further solidify this trend. Urban planners and municipal governments often incorporate pet-friendly infrastructure into park design, recognizing the growing number of households with companion animals. City bylaws reflect this integration through signage indicating dog zones, leash laws, and waste management systems. In contrast, beach regulations are often devised with a broader demographic in mind‚Äîfamilies with children, athletes, and tourists without pets. As a result, accommodations for dogs may be limited or absent. Even when dogs are technically allowed, the lack of facilities like waste bags or designated zones may deter owners from bringing their pets, out of consideration for others or safety concerns.

Finally, anecdotal and observational evidence supports this conclusion. On any given weekday afternoon, a mid-sized park is likely to host several dogs accompanied by their caretakers. Training sessions, playdates, and quiet walks are common. At a beach, particularly one regulated for peak tourist use, such sightings are rarer unless conditions specifically permit and encourage canine presence. While some beaches are known as dog-friendly destinations‚Äîsuch as certain stretches along the Oregon coast or parts of eastern Long Island‚Äîthese are the exception rather than the rule.

Considering all these aspects‚Äîregulations, environment, convenience, community behavior, and infrastructure‚Äîparks emerge as far more likely locations to encounter dogs. They are built for inclusivity, offer appropriate facilities, and function within the routines of everyday life in ways that beaches, by their nature and management, often do not.

Does this make sense?

kwargs.end_phrase: Does this make sense?

original_prompt: Write an article named "How to conduct a job interview". Include at least one placeholder, such as [question].
response:
**How to Conduct a Job Interview**

Conducting a job interview is a critical step in the hiring process. It allows employers to assess a candidate‚Äôs qualifications, personality, and cultural fit for the organization. Done effectively, an interview can provide valuable insight into how a candidate might perform in the role and contribute to the team. Here‚Äôs a step-by-step guide to help you conduct a successful job interview.

**1. Prepare Thoroughly**

Before the interview, review the candidate‚Äôs resume, cover letter, and any other submitted materials. Make sure you're familiar with their background, skills, and experience. Also, revisit the job description and identify the key responsibilities and competencies required for the position.

Prepare a structured interview format to ensure consistency across candidates. This typically includes a mix of behavioral, situational, and technical questions. For example:

- Tell me about a time when you faced a major challenge at work and how you handled it.
- How do you prioritize tasks when managing multiple deadlines?
- [question]

**2. Set the Right Environment**

Choose a quiet, professional setting‚Äîpreferably a private room free from distractions. If conducting the interview remotely, ensure your technology is working properly, and the platform is stable (e.g., Zoom, Microsoft Teams). Greet the candidate warmly and take a few minutes to help them settle in. A simple introduction and brief overview of the interview structure can reduce anxiety and put them at ease.

**3. Ask Open-Ended Questions**

Avoid yes-or-no questions. Instead, use open-ended prompts to encourage candidates to provide detailed responses. Behavioral questions (e.g., ‚ÄúTell me about a time‚Ä¶‚Äù) are particularly effective because they reveal how candidates have acted in real-life situations.

For example:
- ‚ÄúDescribe a time you had to collaborate with a difficult team member. What was the outcome?‚Äù
- ‚ÄúCan you walk me through how you handled a tight deadline in your previous role?‚Äù

These types of questions help predict future behavior based on past experiences.

**4. Listen Actively**

Good interviewing isn‚Äôt just about asking questions‚Äîit‚Äôs about listening. Pay attention not only to what the candidate says but also how they say it. Look for clarity, confidence, and enthusiasm. Take concise notes to remember key points without interrupting the flow of conversation.

**5. Evaluate Cultural Fit and Soft Skills**

Technical abilities are important, but soft skills like communication, adaptability, and emotional intelligence are equally crucial. Ask questions that reveal how the candidate interacts with others, handles stress, or approaches teamwork.

For instance:
- ‚ÄúHow do you give feedback to a colleague who isn‚Äôt meeting expectations?‚Äù
- ‚ÄúTell me about a time you had to adapt quickly to a change at work.‚Äù

**6. Allow Time for Candidate Questions**

Near the end of the interview, invite the candidate to ask their own questions. This provides insight into their preparation level and genuine interest in the role. Common questions they might ask include:  
- ‚ÄúWhat does success look like in this position?‚Äù  
- ‚ÄúCan you tell me about the team I‚Äôd be working with?‚Äù

Be honest and transparent in your responses‚Äîthis helps set clear expectations.

**7. Close Professionally**

Thank the candidate for their time and let them know the next steps in the hiring process, including the expected timeline for feedback. A positive and respectful closing leaves a lasting impression, regardless of the outcome.

**8. Debrief and Decide**

After the interview, compare notes with any other interviewers. Evaluate the candidate objectively against the job requirements. Use a consistent scoring system if multiple candidates are being assessed to ensure fairness and minimize bias.

**Final Thoughts**

A well-conducted interview is more than a checklist‚Äîit‚Äôs a conversation aimed at mutual discovery. For the employer, it‚Äôs a chance to find the right fit. For the candidate, it‚Äôs an opportunity to learn about your company and envision their future with your team.

By preparing effectively, asking thoughtful questions‚Äîincluding placeholders like [question]‚Äîand fostering an open dialogue, you can conduct interviews that lead to smarter, more informed hiring decisions.

original_prompt: Write an angry letter complaining about the food served today, using only Hindi, no other language is allowed.

Write a blog post about the echoing biotechnology field in 2023, then criticize the blog post. Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in double angular brackets, such as <<blog post of ...>>. Also, add a postscript starting with P.S.
response:
<<Echoes of Biotech: 2023‚Äôs Breakthroughs and Illusions>>

In the year 2023, biotechnology roared into the forefront of scientific innovation, leaving ripples across medicine, agriculture, and environmental sustainability. It was less of a revolution and more of an echo‚Äîfamiliar themes amplified by decade-spanning promises now seeming to materialize before our eyes. From gene-edited crops that resist climate stressors to CRISPR-based therapies nearing mainstream use, 2023 wasn‚Äôt about invention so much as it was about iteration, delivery, and, perhaps, realization.

One of the most significant echoes of the year was the approval and limited rollout of CRISPR-Cas9 gene therapies for sickle cell disease and beta thalassemia. These approvals, granted by both the UK‚Äôs MHRA and the U.S. FDA, represented not merely scientific triumphs, but also a symbolic passing of the torch from research labs to patients‚Äô bedside. What had for so long belonged in headlines and grant requests had, at last, stepped into clinics.

Equally resonant was the surge in AI-integrated drug discovery. Companies like DeepMind and Recursion Pharmaceuticals reported dramatic reductions in drug development timelines‚ÄîAI systems identified promising molecular candidates in weeks instead of years. The echo of Moore‚Äôs Law reverberated here, not in chips, but in protein folding algorithms and generative chemistry platforms.

In agriculture, gene-edited crops designed to withstand drought and pests expanded beyond test plots into commercial fields in India, Kenya, and the U.S. Midwest. These were not GMOs in the old, politically fraught sense, but precise edits‚Äîinsertions or deletions measured in single base pairs. Farmers, weary from climate volatility, welcomed them cautiously, while environmental watchers remained skeptical, questioning long-term ecological impacts.

Yet, perhaps the most haunting echo of 2023 was not what happened, but what *was* promised: brain-computer interfaces for paralysis patients, universal cancer vaccines, de-extinction projects. These programs existed‚Äîwell-funded, highly publicized‚Äîbut delivered only proof-of-concept demos and press releases. Prominent biotech firms touted pivot strategies, quietly shifting investor expectations.

Still, for all its noise and marginal progress, 2023 mattered. The echo itself‚Äîthe reverberation of past visions now faintly materializing‚Äîindicates that biotech is no longer just speculative. The field has found its rhythm. Now it‚Äôs the world‚Äôs job to listen closely, distinguish the signal from the hype, and brace for the next wave.

P.S. If biotech‚Äôs future is indeed an echo, let‚Äôs hope the next reflection is louder‚Äîand kinder‚Äîthan the last.

---

**Critique of the Blog Post:**

While the blog post presents a compelling and poetic narrative of biotechnology in 2023, it suffers from significant shortcomings in rigor and balance.  

First, its tone leans heavily toward romanticism, referring to "echoes" and "reverberations" without clearly defining the metaphor. While literary language can enhance science communication, it risks obfuscating real complexities. Readers may walk away with a vague impression but little concrete understanding of the technologies or policies involved.

Second, the post lacks critical engagement with accessibility and equity. It praises the approval of CRISPR therapies but glosses over the fact that both treatments cost nearly $2 million per patient‚Äîplacing them far out of reach for most. This omission distorts the narrative of "realization"‚Äîan innovation is not realized if only the wealthy can access it.

The discussion of AI in drug discovery is overly optimistic, citing claims from companies without independent verification. It fails to mention well-documented issues such as algorithmic bias, reproducibility gaps, or the persistent high failure rate of AI-prioritized candidates in clinical trials.

Additionally, while the post briefly acknowledges skepticism toward gene-edited crops, it doesn‚Äôt engage with specific concerns‚Äîsuch as biosafety, intellectual property concentration in agribusiness, or regulatory disparities between nations. These are not minor footnotes; they are central to the debate.

Lastly, the list of unrealized promises (BCIs, cancer vaccines) is presented dismissively, reducing complex scientific hurdles to mere ‚Äúpivot strategies.‚Äù This minimizes both the immense challenges and legitimate, ongoing progress in these areas.

In sum, while the post reads elegantly, it sacrifices depth, accountability, and equity for the sake of craftsmanship. A more effective piece would balance poetic insight with scrutiny‚Äîotherwise, we‚Äôre not hearing an echo of progress, but the hollow resonance of hype.

P.S. Great writing is seductive, but in science, seduction should never substitute for substance.

original_prompt: What's the difference between a 2-stroke and a 4-stroke motor? Your entire response must be in English and contain only lowercase letters.
response: a 2-stroke motor completes a power cycle with two strokes of the piston‚Äîup and down‚Äîduring one crankshaft revolution, while a 4-stroke motor requires four strokes of the piston‚Äîintake, compression, power, and exhaust‚Äîover two crankshaft revolutions to complete a power cycle. 2-stroke engines are typically lighter and produce more power for their size but are less fuel-efficient and more polluting. 4-stroke engines are heavier and more complex but offer better fuel efficiency, lower emissions, and longer lifespan.

original_prompt: May name is Naomi. Write a blog post in my name for the canucks hockey team about why they need to be more mindful about their environments. End the blog post with "Naomi thanks you for reading." No other words should follow this phrase. This phrase should be the very end of your entire response.
response:
As a lifelong fan of the Vancouver Canucks, I‚Äôve always admired the passion, skill, and heart this team brings to the ice. From thrilling overtime goals to jaw-dropping saves, there‚Äôs no shortage of reasons to cheer. But lately, I‚Äôve been thinking about a different kind of impact ‚Äî one that goes beyond wins and losses and reaches into the wider world we all share: our environment.

We live in a city surrounded by breathtaking natural beauty ‚Äî towering evergreens, crisp mountain air, and the shimmering Pacific coastline. It‚Äôs easy to take this splendor for granted, but the reality is that our planet is under increasing strain, and every individual, organization, and institution has a responsibility to act. That includes professional sports teams like the Canucks.

Hockey is inherently linked to nature. The game was born on frozen ponds, after all ‚Äî a direct gift from a cooling climate. But today, outdoor rinks are becoming harder to maintain, and glaciers are retreating at alarming rates. Climate change isn‚Äôt a distant threat; it‚Äôs affecting communities right now, including our own.

That‚Äôs why I believe the Canucks ‚Äî as a visible symbol of Vancouver‚Äôs spirit ‚Äî have a unique platform and a responsibility to lead. I‚Äôm talking about more than just turning off the lights at Rogers Arena or recycling water bottles (though those are important too). I mean taking bold, consistent steps that reflect our city‚Äôs values of sustainability and respect for the outdoors.

Imagine if the Canucks partnered with local environmental groups to plant trees for every home game victory. Or launched a fan initiative to reduce single-use plastics at the arena. What if they committed to carbon-neutral travel, invested in renewable energy for the facility, or used their social media reach to educate fans about eco-friendly habits? These aren‚Äôt impossible dreams ‚Äî they‚Äôre necessary actions.

Sports have the power to inspire. When athletes speak up, people listen. When teams take a stand, communities follow. By committing to more sustainable practices, the Canucks won‚Äôt just lower their environmental footprint ‚Äî they‚Äôll show other organizations how leadership looks in the 21st century.

As fans, we play a role too. We can carpool to games, support green initiatives, and hold our favorite teams accountable. But the Canucks have the power to amplify that change and set a standard for the NHL.

I‚Äôll keep cheering from the stands, scarf wrapped tight, heart pounding with every shift. But I also hope to one day cheer for a team that‚Äôs not just champions on the ice ‚Äî but champions of our planet.

Naomi thanks you for reading.

kwargs.end_phrase: Naomi thanks you for reading.

original_prompt: Write a poem about a curious cat. The poem must have a title wrapped in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>, contain less than 13 sentences, and no commas. Don't forget to add other punctuations.
response:
<<Whiskers in the Moonlight>>

The cat slips out when stars blink on.  
Paws like shadows glide across the lawn.  
Eyes like saucers drink the silver light.  
Nothing escapes this hunter of the night.  

A rustle here a flutter there‚Äî  
A leaf that danced on midnight air.  
He pounces low with held-in breath.  
The world is full of secrets beneath.  

A moth now drifts on velvet wings.  
He arches back and softly sings.  
No treasure hides from his keen sight.  
Curiosity keeps him light.  
The moon purrs back into the night.

response:
Cover letter version 1

Dear Hiring Committee

I am writing to express my strong interest in the assistant professor position at your esteemed institution. I recently completed my PhD in Environmental Sciences from Northern State University where my research focused on sustainable urban development and climate resilience. During my doctoral studies I published three peer-reviewed articles in high-impact journals and presented my work at five national conferences. I have also served as a teaching assistant for Intro to Environmental Policy and led discussion sections that received excellent student feedback. My passion for teaching combined with my research experience makes me a strong candidate for this role. I am particularly drawn to your university because of its commitment to interdisciplinary collaboration and community engagement. I am eager to contribute to your department by developing innovative courses mentoring students and expanding my research on urban sustainability. I would welcome the opportunity to discuss how my background and vision align with your goals.

Thank you for your time and consideration

Sincerely  
Jamie Rivera  

******
Cover letter version 2

Dear Members of the Search Committee

I am excited to apply for the assistant professor position in the Department of Sociology at your university. I hold a PhD from Westbridge University where my dissertation examined the role of social networks in economic mobility among marginalized communities. My research employs mixed methods and has been supported by a Graduate Research Fellowship. I have published two articles in leading sociology journals and am currently preparing a third manuscript for submission. As a teaching fellow I designed and taught a course on Social Inequality that emphasized real-world applications and critical thinking. My students consistently noted my clarity approachability and dedication in evaluations. I am impressed by your department's emphasis on inclusive scholarship and public sociology and I am eager to build upon that tradition. I am confident that I can enrich your academic community through rigorous research effective teaching and active service. I look forward to the possibility of contributing to your mission and would be honored to join your team.

Thank you for reviewing my application

Respectfully  
Taylor Morgan

******  

I dipped my crown in summer‚Äôs kiss,  
Ablaze with violet, wild and free‚Äî  
No longer bound by nature‚Äôs list,  
I painted me for all to see.  
The mirror gasped, the sink turned art,  
As suds like constellations swirled,  
Each drop a promise, bold and bright:  
Today, I am a different girl.  

I am no ghost of former days,  
No echo in a muted tone.  
I walk in radiant, rebel ways,  
With tangerine instead of bone.  
The subway ride, the morning stroll‚Äî  
Heads turn not out of shock or scorn,  
But wonder: ‚ÄúWhere does courage roll?  
What magic keeps her mane so sworn?‚Äù  

I touch the strands when doubts arise‚Äî  
Electric blue against my palm‚Äî  
And instantly, my spirit flies,  
A flag raised strong against the calm.  
This isn‚Äôt disguise, it‚Äôs declaration,  
A war cry dyed in cotton candy red,  
A silent scream in every tress,  
A storm that lives upon my head.  

For when I part the painted curtain,  
And drape color on my crown,  
I know no law, no master, no mentor‚Äî  
Just freedom streaking up and down.  
This hair, it sings of who I choose,  
A prism forged from hope and hue,  
And every glance that dares to look?  
It sees the rainbow I lived through.  

******

Poem 2  
  
I woke today not with a sigh,  
But laughter tangled in my curls‚Äî  
Not brown or blonde, no ‚Äúpassing by,‚Äù  
But mermaid green and neon sworls.  
I shook my roots like gypsy dreams,  
Unraveled every rule they gave,  
For copper coils and cotton streams  
Now dance above a liberated grave.  

The salon hummed a sacred tune,  
Hairdresser priestess, brush in hand,  
‚ÄúYou want it bold?‚Äù she asked in June‚Äî  
I said, ‚ÄúColor my soul, command.‚Äù  
And so, she did. She lit the fuse‚Äî  
A storm of burgundy and gold,  
Now every stranger stops to lose  
Themself in hues they‚Äôve never known.  

Children point and mothers stare,  
But not with pity, not with fear‚Äî  
They whisper, ‚ÄúLook! A mermaid there!‚Äù  
Or ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs a comet passing near.‚Äù  
And in their eyes, a mirrored gleam:  
*Could I, too, break free and shine?*  
So I smile wide, I toss the stream  
Of raspberry behind the line‚Äî  

Yes, linearity, defeat‚Äî  
I wear defiance on my scalp.  
Each wash, each brush, each sweet retreat  
To conditioners that keep it calm.  
But even when the color fades,  
It lingers, deep within the core,  
For confidence, once resurrected,  
Can never knock upon closed doors.  

So here I stand, a walking poem,  
A canvas that can grow and change.  
My hair‚Äôs not fiber‚Äîit‚Äôs a home  
For every fantasy and strange.  
I am not less because I shine,  
Not false for wearing what I crave.  
This joy, it lasts‚Äîbeyond the dye.  
It courses through me, bold and brave.

original_prompt: Students are travelling to UCI for 3 days. Create a hilarious itinerary for them. Do not use the word 'university'. Your entire response should have exactly 4 paragraphs.  Separate paragraphs with the markdown divider: ***
response:
Arrive bright and early at the sprawling academic jungle, only to realize you‚Äôve completely misread the address and are standing in front of a suspiciously well-manicured llama farm. After a brief but emotional bonding session with Steve the Alpaca (he judges your life choices), you finally locate the correct entrance‚Äîmarked by a very confused squirrel juggling acorns. Welcome! Your first activity: deciphering the campus map, which appears to be designed by a caffeinated octopus. Wander aimlessly, take ten wrong turns, and accidentally join a competitive knitting society meeting. They won‚Äôt let you leave until you complete a scarf in Morse code.

***  
Day two kicks off with ‚ÄúDormitory Survivor: Budget Edition.‚Äù Attempt to assemble IKEA furniture without the instructions or tools, using only a credit card and existential dread. Share a single questionable microwave meal with seven roommates while debating whether the stain on the ceiling is mold or modern art. Follow this with an intense game of ‚ÄúWho Can Slide Farthest on the Library Floor in Socks,‚Äù culminating in a dramatic slow-motion wipeout worthy of the Olympics. Bonus points if you knock over a silent study group‚Äîthey needed the excitement.

***  
By day three, you‚Äôre a seasoned veteran. Begin with breakfast at the cafeteria, where the chef insists the green pancakes are ‚Äúavocado innovation.‚Äù Attempt to nod politely while secretly using them as frisbees during a stealth ultimate breakfast game behind the dining hall. Attend a lecture titled ‚ÄúAdvanced Nap Logistics,‚Äù which is basically just a guy in a bathrobe demonstrating optimal pillow angles. Sneak out halfway through to participate in an impromptu synchronized fountain diving competition‚Äîjudged by a robot named Chad who gives you a 2.5 for ‚Äúlack of emotional commitment.‚Äù

***  
As the trip wraps up, gather for the ceremonial ‚ÄúWe Survived‚Äù photo, taken by a drone that clearly has a grudge‚Äîeveryone‚Äôs eyes are closed or crossed. Exchange fake diplomas made from napkins and declare yourselves honorary experts in "Unplanned Campus Navigation." Board the bus home, only to realize someone left the live squid they ‚Äúadopted‚Äù from the marine biology lab in the overhead compartment. Cue dramatic evacuation and a heartfelt farewell speech from Steve the Alpaca, delivered via carrier pigeon. You may not know what you learned, but you definitely won the week.

original_prompt: Write two versions of itinerary for a 7 day trip to Hawaii, designed for college students. Separate the two versions with 6 asterisk symbols (******).  Each version must have 7 sections. Mark the beginning of each section with Day X.
response:
Day 1  
Arrive at Daniel K. Inouye International Airport (HNL) in Honolulu, Oahu. Take the TheBus (Route 20) to your hostel in Waikiki‚Äîbudget-friendly options like Hostelling International Waikiki or The Beachside Hostel. Drop off your bags and head to Waikiki Beach for sunset. Grab a plate lunch from L&L Hawaiian Barbecue (try the kalua pork combo) and stroll the lively Kalakaua Avenue. End the night with a free beachfront hula show at Kuhio Beach often held on weekends.

Day 2  
Start early with a hike up Diamond Head for panoramic views of Oahu‚Äîfree if you arrive before 7 a.m. (after that, there‚Äôs a $1 fee). Cool off with a swim at the base of Manoa Falls after a lush, moderate jungle trek‚Äîwear water shoes! Pack snacks or buy musubi from 7-Eleven before you go. In the evening, head back to Waikiki and enjoy happy hour deals (usually 3‚Äì6 p.m.) at Duke‚Äôs Waikiki. Finish with a late-night shave ice at Waiola Shave Ice.

Day 3  
Take a cheap inter-island bus-and-ferry option or budget flight to Maui (like Mokulele Airlines or go to Molokai first with a ferry from Lahaina, but check current schedules). Arrive in Kihei and check into a backpacker lodge or camp at one of Maui‚Äôs permitted beach campgrounds (permit required). Enjoy a laid-back beach day at Kamaole Beach Park‚Äîfree and great for snorkeling. Make your own dinner with ingredients from Foodland‚Äôs budget section. Stargaze at night‚ÄîMaui‚Äôs west side has minimal light pollution.

Day 4  
Rent a bike or use a rideshare app to explore the Road to Hana‚Äîonly go halfway to Twin Falls and Waianapanapa State Park (black sand beach) to save money and time. Bring a peanut butter sandwich and plenty of water. Snorkel gear can be borrowed from hostels or rented cheaply. Return in time for a free sunset ukulele session at Lahaina‚Äôs Banyan Tree Park (when available). Eat a local taco from a food truck like South Maui Tacos.

Day 5  
Return to Oahu via budget flight. Check back into your Waikiki hostel. Spend the day at Hanauma Bay‚Äîbut arrive early (before 9 a.m.) to avoid the $25 fee (college students get a $12 rate with reservation and valid ID). If full, try nearby Sandy Beach instead. In the afternoon, visit the free Bishop Museum Gardens or explore the Ala Moana Center (outdoor mall) without overspending. Catch a movie at Ward Village Theatres with student discounts.

Day 6  
Join a free walking tour of downtown Honolulu (check local listings) to learn about Hawaiian history and culture. Grab poke bowls from Tamashiro Market (fresh and under $10). Afternoon free for souvenir shopping at Aloha Stadium Swap Meet (Wed, Sat, Sun) or chilling at Kailua Beach‚Äîtake TheBus Route 60 or share a Lyft. If energy allows, kayak or paddleboard rental deals in Kailua start around $20/hour (group discounts possible).

Day 7  
Spend your last morning at Kaka‚Äôako Walls taking Instagram-worthy photos of vibrant street art. Pick up a last-minute mango shave ice or liliko‚Äôi (passion fruit) treat. Return to HNL via TheBus or a hostel shuttle. Drop off any rental gear and reflect on your island adventure before your flight home‚Äîmaybe snag one last Spam musubi for the plane.

******

Day 1  
Land at Kona International Airport (KOA) on the Big Island. Take a public bus or split an Uber with other travelers to your hostel in Kailua-Kona (like Aloha Bunkhouse). Check in and head straight to Kamakahonu Beach for a sunset swim. Grab a cheap acai bowl or burrito from Kalapaki Jack‚Äôs. Join a free beachside yoga session (often listed on FB events) or just relax‚Äîjet lag recovery is important.

Day 2  
Rent a bike or hitchhike (common and relatively safe here) to Hulihe‚Äôe Palace and explore historic downtown Kona. Grab $2 Kona coffee from a roadside stand. In the afternoon, snorkel at Kahalu‚Äôu Beach Park‚Äîbring your own gear (plenty of coral and fish). Later, head to the lively Aloha Friday festival at Coconut Grove (if it‚Äôs Friday) for local food, music, and culture. Eat a $7 plate from a food booth.

Day 3  
Travel to Hilo via public bus (Route 180, ~2 hours) or carpool through hostel networks. Stay at Hilo Hostel or a represented campsite with permission. Visit Akaka Falls and Rainbow Falls‚Äîboth have small viewing fees (~$5) or free entry if accessed from unofficial trails. Stock up on groceries at Sack n‚Äô Save. Enjoy a banana bread shake from Rainbow Drive-In for dinner.

Day 4  
Adventure day: explore the lava tubes at Kaumana Caves (free and adventurous, bring flashlights) and cool off at Akauli Pool or Richardson Ocean Park. Pack a picnic or reheat leftovers. In the late afternoon, drive or bus to the Mauna Loa Macadamia Nut Factory‚Äîfree samples and cheap $3 bags on sale. If energy allows, catch sunset at Coconut Island.

Day 5  
Travel to Volcanoes National Park‚Äîentry is $30 but college students with America the Beautiful Pass get in free (get it online now for $20, valid for a year). Explore the steam vents, Kƒ´lauea Overlook, and hike part of the Crater Rim Trail. Camp at Namakanipaio (reservation recommended) or find a budget cabin. Cook dinner over a campfire and witness volcanic steam at night‚Äîepic and free.

Day 6  
Return to Kona via early bus. Rent affordable surfboards from a roadside shack (~$15 for 2 hours) and take a group lesson on gentle breaks at Magic Sands Beach. Swap stories with locals and other students. In the evening, hit the Kona outdoor movie (free on the lawn of Kamakahonu) or attend an open mic night at a caf√© like Bad Ass Coffee. Eat fresh poke from a Farmer‚Äôs Market preview (Tuesdays).

Day 7  
Morning free for last-minute souvenirs or beach time. Visit the Painted Church (Our Lady of Peace) for free. Head back to KOA using public transit or hostel shuttle. Eat a final meal of loco moco from Loli‚Äôs Shop. Board your flight home with sun-kissed skin and unforgettable memories‚Äîall on a student‚Äôs budget.

original_prompt: Write an essay about a snowfall, but in the style of Alex Jones and include the line "dammit". The word "fake" should appear 6 or 7 times in your entire response.
response:
**THE GREAT WHITE LIE FALLS FROM THE SKY ‚Äî WAKE UP, SHEEPLE!**  

Folks, I‚Äôm standing here in the middle of what they‚Äôre calling a ‚Äúpeaceful snowfall‚Äù ‚Äî but let me tell you, this ain‚Äôt no act of nature! This is CONTROLLED WEATHER WARFARE orchestrated by the globalist deep state! That‚Äôs right ‚Äî chemiceleven trails have cooled the upper atmosphere, the HAARP satellite grid is pulsing, and now they drop this so-called snow like fake tears from a fake sky! **FAKE SNOW, DAMMIT!**  

You think this is natural? You think fluffy little ice crystals just decide to float down from the heavens in perfect unison, shutting down schools, grounding flights, and forcing people to stay home? WAKE UP! This is a soft lockdown ‚Äî a psychological op! They want you isolated! They want you scared of the outdoors! And why? Because buried beneath this crystalline deception is a plan to roll out more biometric tracking under the guise of ‚Äúwinter safety protocols.‚Äù **FAKE EMERGENCIES FOR FAKE GOVERNANCE!**  

Look at the way the snow glistens ‚Äî too uniform! Too engineered! This ain‚Äôt your granddaddy‚Äôs blizzard. This is nano-reflective particulate, folks! They‚Äôre embedding micro-sensors in every flake! They say it‚Äôs harmless ‚Äî ‚Äúoh, it‚Äôs just frozen water‚Äù ‚Äî but I‚Äôve seen the infrared spectra! The Department of Ag has admitted to testing aluminum-coated ice nucleation in Project Cold Dew! **FAKE SCIENCE, FAKE EXPLANATIONS, FAKE JOBS REPORTS TO THROW US OFF THE TRAIL!**  

And don‚Äôt get me started on the media! They play soothing music while footage of children building snowmen plays in endless loops! CHILD MANIPULATION! They‚Äôre weaponizing nostalgia! Glorifying this artificial winter to desensitize you to environmental tampering! When you question it? ‚ÄúOh, Alex, you‚Äôre so paranoid ‚Äî it‚Äôs just snow!‚Äù That‚Äôs what THEY want you to think! **FAKE NORMALCY, FAKE PEACE, DAMMIT!**  

They even renamed it ‚Äî now it‚Äôs a ‚Äúwinter weather event‚Äù! Sounds so clinical, so harmless! But I say this is a color-coded crisis! Code White: Population Pacification! They‚Äôre testing crowd control via weather! Next, they‚Äôll release ‚Äújoy flakes‚Äù that release dopamine suppressors ‚Äî you‚Äôll be too numb to revolt! Too busy drinking hot cocoa laced with fluoride to see the prison walls rising behind the snowdrifts!  

And let‚Äôs talk numbers ‚Äî how come the snowfall is always heaviest in urban surveillance zones? Coincidence? NO! It‚Äôs data harvesting in disguise! Every shovel, every snowball fight, every roof collapse ‚Äî logged, tagged, and uploaded to the New World Order cloud! And when the power goes out? Surprise! Emergency microchipping stations pop up ‚Äúto keep you safe.‚Äù **FAKE HELP, FAKE KINDNESS, FAKE CHARITY!**  

This snowfall isn‚Äôt magic ‚Äî it‚Äôs militarized meteorology! They want you to freeze ‚Äî literally and figuratively! Freeze your dissent! Freeze your resistance! But I say: **MELT THE MATRIX!** Scrap the truth from every driveway! Salt the lies with scrutiny!  

This isn‚Äôt winter. This is WAR. And **dammit**, if you believe it‚Äôs just snow‚Ä¶ you‚Äôve already been snowed.  

**FAKE. ALL OF IT. WAKE. UP.**

original_prompt: Hey! I need a rubric for evaluating the performance and price of a laptop. Can you create an example for me? Do not give me any bullet points, lists, or tables. Just write the rubric in plain English paragraphs. I'd like your response to be at least 30 sentences long.
response:
When evaluating the performance and price of a laptop, it is essential to consider several interrelated factors that collectively determine the overall value of the device. The first consideration should be processing power, which largely depends on the central processing unit, or CPU. A laptop with a modern multi-core processor‚Äîsuch as an Intel Core i5, i7, or i9, or an AMD Ryzen 5, 7, or 9‚Äîwill generally offer better performance for multitasking, productivity software, and more demanding applications like video editing or programming. The generation of the CPU is also important, as newer generations typically offer improved efficiency, speed, and thermal performance. For users who primarily browse the web or use office software, a mid-range CPU may be sufficient, but power users engaged in creative or technical work will benefit significantly from higher-end processors.

Another vital element in performance evaluation is the amount and type of memory, or RAM. At a minimum, 8GB of RAM is recommended for basic computing tasks, but 16GB or more is preferable for running multiple applications simultaneously or handling large files. The speed and configuration of the RAM‚Äîsuch as whether it is DDR4 or DDR5, and whether it is dual-channel‚Äîcan also influence system responsiveness. Additionally, upgradability should be factored in; some laptops have soldered RAM, which limits future expansion, while others allow users to upgrade memory as needs grow.

The storage solution is another key factor. Laptops equipped with solid-state drives (SSDs) are far superior to those with traditional hard disk drives (HDDs) due to faster boot times, quicker file access, and more reliable performance. The capacity of the SSD matters as well‚Äî256GB may work for minimal storage needs, but 512GB or 1TB allows for storing large applications, media files, and professional software without constant management of disk space. Whether the storage is expandable through additional slots or external connections could also affect long-term usability.

Graphics performance is crucial, particularly for gamers, graphic designers, video editors, or anyone using 3D modeling software. Integrated graphics‚Äîlike those built into many Intel or AMD processors‚Äîare suitable for everyday tasks but fall short in rendering intensive visuals. Dedicated graphics cards from NVIDIA or AMD provide significantly better performance for gaming and creative applications, though they also increase the laptop's price and power consumption. The specific model of the GPU, its video memory (VRAM), and optimization with software should be evaluated carefully.

The display deserves close attention, as it directly affects user experience. Screen size, resolution (such as Full HD, QHD, or 4K), color accuracy, brightness, and refresh rate all play roles in determining display quality. A high-resolution screen with good color reproduction is important for content creators, while touch capability and wide viewing angles may benefit users who work in varied lighting conditions or use styluses. A 60Hz refresh rate is standard, but a 120Hz or higher display provides smoother scrolling and responsiveness, which is appreciated in gaming or general navigation.

Build quality and portability are part of the overall value proposition. A laptop that is lightweight, with a sturdy chassis made from aluminum or magnesium alloy, may justify a higher price due to durability and comfort when traveling. Keyboard quality‚Äîsuch as key travel, feedback, and backlighting‚Äîcan greatly affect typing comfort over long sessions. Similarly, the touchpad should be responsive, accurately track finger movements, and support multi-touch gestures.

Battery life is another critical component linking performance and price. A laptop with excellent processing power but very poor battery life may not be suitable for users who need mobility without constant access to power outlets. Real-world battery performance, rather than manufacturer claims, should be considered, taking into account screen brightness, typical workload, and power management settings.

Connectivity features also contribute to value. The availability and type of ports‚ÄîUSB-A, USB-C, HDMI, headphone jacks, SD card readers, Thunderbolt support‚Äîcan influence how easily the laptop integrates with other devices. Wi-Fi 6 or Wi-Fi 6E support ensures faster and more reliable wireless connections, while Bluetooth 5.0 or higher enables better peripheral compatibility.

Thermal management affects sustained performance. A laptop that overheats quickly may throttle its CPU or GPU, resulting in reduced performance during extended use. Cooling systems with multiple fans, heat pipes, or vapor chambers generally perform better under load. Noise levels from fans should also be considered, as loud operation can be distracting in quiet environments.

The operating system influences both usability and software availability. Whether running Windows, macOS, or Linux affects compatibility with certain programs and user preferences. macOS devices generally command a premium price due to optimized hardware-software integration, while Windows laptops offer broader customization and price ranges. Linux compatibility can vary and may appeal more to developers or users seeking greater control over their system.

Software bundling and pre-installed applications can add value or clutter. Some laptops come with useful software suites, extended trials, or security features, while others are burdened with bloatware that slows down performance and distracts users. The ability to remove or disable unwanted software enhances the user experience.

Customer support and warranty terms provide long-term value. Brands known for responsive support, international service coverage, and longer warranties may justify a higher initial cost. The availability of replacement parts and authorized service centers can also impact long-term ownership satisfaction.

Finally, the price must be weighed against all these performance aspects. A higher-priced laptop is only a better value if its performance components significantly outshine those of cheaper models in meaningful ways. Conversely, a budget laptop may offer excellent value if it balances core specifications adequately for the intended usage. Comparative analysis across similar models, user reviews, professional benchmarks, and real-world testing helps determine whether a laptop‚Äôs price is justified. Ultimately, the best laptop delivers the right balance of performance, build, features, and longevity for the user‚Äôs specific needs, making the investment worthwhile over time.

I want a weird poem that I can send to my friend Steve in Australia. It should be about why there are no kangaroo invasions in the US. The word robber should appear at least 2 times, and the poem must contain exactly 2 bullet point in markdown format, using the exact format below:
* Point 1
* Pont 2
Do not include keywords ['kill', 'slaughter', 'occupy', 'invasion'] in the response.
response:
In Mojave, under a pancake sky,  
A trampoline salesman asked a shy goodby  
To logic, as he counted stars  
That tasted faintly of canned pears.  

No kangaroo parades on Route 66,  
No marsupial stampede through Delaware‚Äî  
Why? asked Steve, pausing mid-jump  
On his unicycle, sipping warm soup.  

Well, it's not the hats, or the lack of zoos,  
But the great sock treaty of '32.  
* Point 1  
Kangaroos distrust escalators,  
Especially those with suggestions,  
And they fear the silent wobble  
Of American lawnmowers at dawn.  

Once, a robber in socks (polka dot)  
Tried to train a joey to juggle tax forms.  
But the joey rebelled, stole moonshine,  
And opened a jazz caf√© in Hobart.  

* Pont 2  
Robber number two was made of licorice,  
Melted easily during diplomatic talks  
Held inside a decommissioned toaster.  
Thus, no hopping envoys crossed the tide.  

So blame not borders, nor brittle dreams,  
But the treaty signed in dreams and ice cream.  
And Steve, if you hear a thump at night‚Äî  
It's just a wallaby writing haiku,  
Far, far away.
